thread.title: Corruption Currents: Iran Downplays Impact of Any New Sanctions

author: Ben DiPietro
title: Corruption Currents: Iran Downplays Impact of Any New Sanctions
text:
0 COMMENTS Iran's oil minister, Bijan Namdar Zanganeh, speaks at an energy exhibition in Tehran on Sunday. Photo: ABEDIN TAHERKENAREH/EPA-EFE/REX
A daily roundup of corruption news from across the Web. We also provide a daily roundup of important risk & compliance stories vi a our daily newsletter, , which readers can sign up for here . Follow us on Twitter at @WSJRisk.
Bribery:
Is the Council on Europe dragging its feet in punishing lawmakers suspected of taking bribes to stifle discussion on human-rights violations in Azerbaijan? (NYT)
Senior officials in the Israeli city of Beit Shemesh were arrested Sunday on bribery charges. The article contained no responses from the individuals or their lawyers. (Haaretz)
Employees in Ukraine’s internal security department were arrested for suspected bribery. The article contained no responses from the suspects. (KP)
A Chinese businessman was arrested on bribery charges in Papua New Guinea. The reports had no response from the man. (RNZ, ABC)
Money Laundering:
The daughter of the head of India’s Rashtriya Janata Dal political party and her husband, who are accused of money laundering, appeared in court Monday. (ANI)
Latvia delayed announcing the new head of its anti-money laundering department so the person can have more time to decide if he or she wants the job. (LSM)
Attorney-client privilege is keeping secret corporate real-estate transaction information out of the hands of investigators in Canada. One attorney says a court order will be needed to make it public. (Star)
Nigeria is implementing a new anti-money laundering regime. (Vanguard)
Cybercrime/Privacy:
How well protected is data about Facebook users that academics have collected? (NYT)
A teen accused of illegally accessing records from a government website in Nova Scotia, Canada, won’t be charged . (CH, GN)
Shareholders of Equifax voted to return all the company’s board members despite the breach the credit-rating company suffered. (Gizmodo)
A lawsuit claims a Wisconsin-based hospital owner delayed telling patients about a data breach and lied to them when it did. The company declined to comment. (WSJ)
Sanctions:
Iran maintains any new western sanctions won’t derail its oil industry. What could happen if new sanctions are imposed? Oil prices keep climbing as the U.S. deadline to withdraw from the Iran nuclear deal approaches. U.S. President Donald Trump slammed former Secretary of State John Kerry for trying to preserve the Iran agreement. (Reuters, MW, WP, Bloomberg, WP)
North Korea is disputing the idea U.S. sanctions are forcing it to the nuclear negotiating table. How much credit does Mr. Trump deserve for bringing North Korea to talks? How will the world really know if North Korea dismantles its nukes? (BI, AP, RCP, NYT)
How is the Russian economy faring under sanctions? (CNBC)
Whistleblowers:
The king of Saudi Arabia announced new protections for whistleblowers who expose corruption. (Reuters, Haaretz, Axios)
A jury in Florida issued a verdict saying a school district that transferred a whistleblower did not do so in retaliation. (Law.com)
General Anticorruption:
The chief executive of a North Carolina health company was sentenced to eight years in prison. (HF)
A federal judge recommended against dismissing fraud charges against a disbarred Kentucky lawyer who asked that the charges be dropped. (LHL)
Is the president of the Philippines sending mixed messages in his fight against corruption? (PS)
A U.S. senator said he placed a hold on $6 million in funding for an anticorruption initiative in Guatemala. (NYT, IC)
